isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - HEATING, VENTILATION, AND AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC) TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - HEATER AND AIR CONDITIONER BLOWER WITH THERMOSTAT TEMPERATURE CONTROL (SLEEPER) - TROUBLESHOOTING

svcprocinfo.para: Before beginning these test procedures, do the following:

item.para: Make sure the vehicle batteries are at 75% state of charge (SOC) or higher. This represents an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 12.4 volts. Batteries with an OCV of 12 volts or less are either completely discharged or have a dead cell.
Check any light or indicator lamp filaments that are suspected of being open (burned out). This is done to avoid unnecessary extensive circuit checks.
Inspect all connectors for loose or damaged pins, wires, etc. Refer to TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

When the technician determines that a fuse is blown, while checking its condition, he is directed to locate the cause of the overload condition and to repair it. While no further instruction on this procedure is listed in the diagnostic tables, the common procedure is as follows: isolate sections of the circuit by disconnecting connectors, and measure the resistance to ground to find the circuit that is shorted to ground. Then locate the damaged spot in the wire or connector and repair.

Diagnostics for circuits that are malfunctioning by sticking in the on position are generally not covered in detail. It is assumed that the technician knows to check for a malfunctioning switch, relay, or solenoid.

entry.para: Does the blower run in either the low, medium, or high speed position?
Remove auxiliary bunk blower relay (147), move key switch to ignition position, and at circuit 13AT measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13AT, then repair.
At relay socket (147), measure voltage from circuit 13AT to 13-GAT.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 13-GAT, 75-GH, 75-GN, 11-GBD to ground adapter (454), then repair.
At (B2) battery stud, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of no or low voltage at (B2) battery stud, then repair.
Remove fuse F10-B [location may vary] and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F10-B and at circuit 14AU, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14AK or 14AU, then repair.
At relay socket (147), measure voltage from circuit 75AX to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AX, then repair.
Bench test auxiliary bunk blower relay (147) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Replace defective auxiliary bunk blower relay.
Bench test auxiliary bunk blower relay (147) by applying +12 volts to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Replace defective auxiliary bunk blower relay.
Re-install (147) and disconnect switch (593). Move key switch to ignition position and at (593) circuit 75AR, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AS or 75AR, then repair.
Test bunk heater blower switch (593) by placing switch in low speed position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to L and B to C.
(593), term. B to L and B to C.
Test bunk heater blower switch (593) by placing switch in medium speed position, and measuring resistance from switch term. B to M, and B to C.
(593), term. B to M, and B to C.
Test bunk heater blower switch (593) by placing switch in high speed position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to H, and B to C.
(593), term. B to H, and B to C.
Re-install blower switch (593). Move key switch to on position. Does blower motor run at low speed when blower switch is set to low position?
Disconnect connector (N/L) and with key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low speed position, measure voltage from circuit 75AC [coming from (593)] to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AC, conn. (N/L), or circuit 75AC, then repair.
Disconnect resistor and thermo fuse assembly (N/L) and with key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low position, measure voltage from circuit 75AC to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AC, then repair.
At blower resistor and thermo fuse assy. (N/L), measure resistance from terminal 1 to 2.
At blower resistor and thermo fuse assy. (N/L), measure resistance from terminal 2 to 3.

Reconnect blower resistor, and disconnect connector (48). With key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low speed position, at (48) circuit 75AT [going to (N/L)], measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AT, then repair.
Remove sleeper high speed relay (584) and reconnect conn. (48). At circuit 75AT, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AT, then repair.
Bench test high speed relay (584) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test high speed relay (584) by applying +12 volts to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Move key switch to ignition position, blower switch to high speed position, and at (584) circuit 75AH, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AH, then repair.
At (584) install a test jumper from cir. 75AF to 75-GH. Disconnect conn. (48) and at circuit 75AF [coming from (584)], measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75AF, then repair.
At conn. (48) measure resistance from circuit 75-GA [going to (454)] to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GA or 11-GBD to ground adapter (454), then repair.
Reconnect conn. (48) and disconnect circuit 75AF from sleeper blower motor. Move key switch to ignition position, blower switch to low speed position, and at circuit 75AF, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AF, then repair.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GA, then repair.
With ignition key in off position, reconnect circuit 75AF. Move key switch to ignition position and with blower switch in low speed position, does blower run?
Remove medium speed relay (585), move key switch to ignition position and blower switch to medium speed position. At cir. 75AN, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AN, then repair.
Remove fuse F10-A [location may vary] and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F10-A, and at relay socket (585) and circuit 75AB, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AW or 75AB, then repair.
Bench test medium speed relay (585) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test medium speed relay (585) by applying +12 volts to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.

Disconnect conn. (48), re-install medium speed relay (585), move key switch to ignition position and blower switch to low speed position. At (48) circuit 75AM [coming from (585)], measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AM, then repair.
Disconnect resistor and thermo fuse assy. (N/L) and reconnect conn. (48). At (N/L) circuit 75AM, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AM, then repair.
Reconnect resistor and thermo fuse conn. (N/L) and remove high speed relay (584). At (584) circuit 75AD, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AD, then repair.
Re-install high speed relay (584). Heater blower circuits check good.
With key switch in ignition position, sleeper blower switch (593) in low position, and sleeper A/C switch (905) in on position, does A/C clutch engage (click once)?
With switches still set, disconnect connector (905) and at circuit 77L, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77L, then repair.
With switches still set, at connector (905) measure voltage from circuit 77L to 75-GL.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 77-GL to sleeper gnd. stud, or 11-GAN to "B"-pillar ground stud, then repair.
Test switch and blocking diode assembly by placing disconnected switch in the on position, and measuring resistance from connector (905) pin A to pin B. NOTE: "+" lead must be on pin A.
Reconnect connector (905), move key switch to ignition position, sleeper blower switch to low, and sleeper A/C switch to on. Does A/C switch indicator illuminate?
With switches still set, disconnect connector (906) and at circuit 77M [coming from (905)], measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77M, then repair.

Remove A/C control relay (144) and reconnect conn. (906). With key switch in ignition position, bunk blower switch in low position, and sleeper A/C switch on, at (144) circuit 77K measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77K or 77M from conn. (906), then repair.
At (144), with switches still set, measure voltage from circuit 77K to 77-GS.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 77-GS, 82-GA, 12-GF, 11-GQ, or 11-GF to left dash panel ground stud, then repair.
Remove fuse F1-B and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F1-B, and at circuit 14Z, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14H or 14Z from (B2), then repair.
At (144) circuit 77T, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77T, then repair.
Bench test A/C control relay (144) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test A/C control relay (144) by applying +12 volts to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.

Re-install A/C control relay (144) and disconnect conn. (162). Set A/C switch (904) to on, blower switch (11) to low, and key switch to ignition position. At (162) circuit 77H, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77H, then repair.
At conn. (162) (going to heater box), measure resistance from circuit 77B to 77F (evaporator temperature must be greater than 34°F).
Disconnect thermostatic switch (N/L), and measure resistance from terminal 1 to 2 (evaporator temperature must be greater than 34°F).
At connector (N/L), removed from thermostatic switch, and circuit 77B, install a jumper wire to gnd. At connector (162) circuit 77B, measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 77B, then repair.
At conn. (N/L), removed from thermostatic switch, and circuit 77F, install a jumper wire to ground. At conn. (162) circuit 77F, going to heater box, measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 77F, then repair.

With thermostatic switch (N/L) and conn. (162) reconnected, remove A/C relay (463)/R6. Move key switch to ignition position, sleeper A/C switch (905) to on, and blower switch (593) to low. At (463)/R6 circuit 77F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77F, then repair.
With switches still set, at relay socket (463)/R6, measure voltage from circuit 77F to 77-G.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 77-G, 58-GA, or 11-G to right dash panel ground stud, then repair.
At relay socket (463)/R6 measure resistance of cir. 77D (terminal that relay pin 86 was in, to term. that relay pin 87 was in).
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 77D, then repair.
At relay socket (463)/R6 install jumper wire from circuit 77F to 77A. Set A/C switch (905) to on, blower switch (593) to low, and key switch to ignition position. Did A/C clutch engage (click once)?
With switches still set, disconnect connector (2) and at circuit 77C [coming from (463)/R6] measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77C, then repair.
With switches still set, reconnect conn. (2) and disconnect compressor connector (N/L). At (N/L) circuit 77C measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77C, then repair.
With switches still set, reconnect conn. (N/L) at the A/C compressor clutch. Does the clutch engage (click once)?
With switches still set, disconnect low pressure safety switch (N/L), and measure voltage from circuit 77E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77C or 77E, then repair.
With switches still set, disconnect high pressure safety switch (N/L), and measure voltage from circuit 77N to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77N, then repair.

At relay socket (463)/R6 move jumper wire to between circuit 77F and 77R. Move key switch to ignition position, A/C switch (904) to on, and blower switch (11) to low. At low pressure safety switch (N/L) circuit 77P, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77R or 77P, then repair.
At high pressure safety switch (N/L) circuit 77J, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 77J, then repair.
Measure resistance of low pressure safety switch (N/L).
If refrigerant charge is within limits, replace defective low pressure switch.
Measure resistance of high pressure safety switch (N/L).
If refrigerant charge is within limits, replace defective high pressure switch.
Bench test A/C relay (463)/R6 by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test A/C relay (463)/R6 by applying +12 volts to terminal 85, ground to terminal 86, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Air conditioner circuits check good. Remove test jumper, re-install relay, and reconnect the separated connectors.
Disconnect conn. (592) and move key switch to ignition position. At (592) circuit 75AL, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AL, then repair.
At conn. (592), measure voltage from circuit 75AL to 75-GS.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GS to sleeper ground stud, or circuit 11-GAN, conn. (942), or circuit 11-GAN to "B"-pillar ground stud, then repair.

Bench test automatic temp. control by applying +12 volts to pin A at connector (592), applying ground to pin C and measuring voltage at pin B to ground. Measure voltage at pin B while turning control knob full CCW, then fully CW.
Full CCW: 12 volts, full CW: 0 volts.
Replace defective automatic temperature control module.
With bench test wiring still installed, and control knob set to center of range, does output voltage at pin B change as warm or cool air is applied to the ambient air sensor?
Replace defective automatic temperature control module.

Reconnect conn. (592), disconnect conn. (162), move key switch to ign. position, and at (162) circuit 75K [coming from (592)], measure voltage to ground while rotating sleeper temp. control fully CCW and CW.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75K, conn. (906) or circuit 75K, then repair.
At connector (162) measure voltage from circuit 75L [coming from (147)] to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75L, then repair.
Reconnect connector (162). Does heater box damper door function properly?
Disconnect heater box damper connector (N/L), and with key switch in ignition position, measure voltage from circuit 75L to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75L, then repair.
At heater box damper connector (N/L), measure voltage from circuit 75L to 75-GL.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GL, 75-G or 11-G to right dash panel ground stud, then repair.
At heater box damper conn. (N/L), measure voltage from circuit 75K to ground while rotating sleeper temp. control fully CCW and CW.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75K, then repair.

Reconnect heater box damper conn. (N/L), move key switch to ignition position, and note if damper door closes completely and opens completely, when sleeper temperature control is moved fully CW and CCW.
Sleeper temp. control circuits check good.
